MS MCQs

    Introduction to object-oriented programming with Python

    »

    1. What is the difference between a class and an object?

      They’re the same thing.

      A class is a blueprint. An object is the concrete instance you build from the blueprint.

      A class has data and an object doesn’t.

      A class has methods and an object doesn’t.


    2. How does Python implement accessors?

      It uses prefixes. One underscore, _, at the beginning of the name indicates this variable is protected. Two underscores, __, make the variable private and will raise an exception if assigned.

      It uses the keywords private and public.

      Everything in a Python class is hidden by default and must be exposed by adding methods that return the variables’ values.

      Add the decorator @public or @private to make something public or private.


    3. Choose the best explanation that explains the keyword self.

      It’s a keyword that refers to the object instance. You can also use the this keyword.

      The self keyword refers to the underlying class of the object.

      The only time the self keyword is used is to refer to members of the object, and it’s passed as a parameter.

      The self keyword refers to the object instance. Variables that are part of the object instance need to be assigned to self. The self keyword is also passed to every method of a class that needs to access the object instance.
